ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The course is a good introduction to the history of ancient state formation. I learned primarily about Mesopotamia and its relation to other states like Mexico and Egypt.
I learned the fundamental elements behind ancient state formation across the world along with the different ways they are studied.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Disorganization is a significant problem with this class. The Canvas page should be completely wiped and re-populated with only the relevant readings. Professor Weiss would do well to use the announcement function on Canvas to post relevant announcements, instead of only saying them in class where half the students don't even show up.
I found the seminars to be very engaging and I always enjoined gong to class. We had a lot of guest speakers which was fun to see their perspectives on very locations that we studied.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Not unless you are looking for a low workload class with minimal expectations for engagement.

I would not recommend this course. To be honest, most of the time it felt like a waste of a credit. The classes taught by Professor Weiss were repetitive, boring, difficult to follow, relatively uninformative, and sometimes downright uncomfortable. Most of the time was spent listening to him ask questions (which could have led to interesting discussions, had he encouraged students to actually answer them) that he then answered himself, usually in long, disjointed rambles. The way he talked about the material was extraordinarily disorganized and made it a challenge to even stay on the same page as him. After guest lectures, which were much more well-organized and enjoyable, Professor Weiss spent the next class mainly just talking smack about the guests and what they did or didn't include in their presentations, which was frankly a disturbing and discouraging thing to see in what should be a constructive, collaborative field. While I don't doubt his experience and contributions as an archaeologist, and I think his ideas regarding civilization genesis and collapse are well-crafted, he was simply not an enjoyable lecturer. The course materials were in complete disarray, with an unorganized Canvas file scheme cluttered with dozens of files from previous years that we didn't even touch. The final essay was more-or-less unrelated to anything we had engaged with in class up to that point, centered on a reading that he didn't post on Canvas, and he didn't post the prompt on Canvas either, so I wasn't even entirely sure what I was meant to write about. Overall, while the readings could be interesting, that was more or less the only positive attribute of the class. I would avoid this course unless you thrive on chaos.
